observationText: The c.6619C > T NF1-mutant hiPSC line was generated by CRISPR/Cas9 editing of a control human iPSC line to introduce a heterozygous NF1 mutation found in NF1 patients. Only a single clone with this mutation could be obtained without additional genomic insertions or deletions.
The c.6619C > T NF1-mutant hiPSCs retained expression of the remaining wild-type NF1 allele and expressed similar levels of NF1 mRNA compared to control iPSC lines.

The c.6619C > T NF1-mutant hiPSCs were successfully differentiated into cerebral organoids, which exhibited increased cell cycle progression and apoptosis compared to isogenic controls when grown for 56 days in vitro.
The c.6619C > T NF1-mutant hiPSCs exhibited increased RAS activity compared to controls when treated with FGF or BDNF growth factors.
Cerebral organoids derived from the c.6619C > T NF1-mutant hiPSCs formed radially organized ventricle-like structures populated by SOX2+ neural progenitor cells by 16 days in vitro.

The c.6619C > T NF1-mutant hiPSCs were successfully differentiated into Schwann cell precursor (SCP) cells using a defined differentiation protocol involving dissociation, replating on Matrigel-coated plates with ROCK inhibitor, and switching to SCP differentiation medium.
The c.6619C > T NF1-mutant hiPSCs retained heterozygosity for the NF1 mutation after five passages, as confirmed by sequencing of the hiPSCs and their derivative cell lines.
